Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Black Hole Accretion Theory and Computation Network
Award.AbstractNarration: This project will create a Theoretical and Computational Astrophysics Network with major nodes at the University of Illinois at Urbana-Champaign, the University of California at Berkeley, and Princeton University, to advance the theory of black hole accretion and outflows. Accretion of matter onto black holes is central to many astrophysical and gravitational phenomena, but current theory lacks self-consistent models both for high accretion rate flows where radiation forces are important, and for low accretion rate flows where collisionless plasma effects are important. The network team brings together expertise in high performance computing techniques, astrophysics, and plasma physics in order to address this need. The team will develop a general relativistic, radiation magnetohydrodynamics code to study luminous accreting black holes, and a multi-fluid relativistic magnetohydrodynamics code with anisotropic electron and ion pressures, conduction, viscosity, and radiative heating and cooling to study slowly accreting systems. These new codes will be used to address fundamental questions about the structure and observational appearance of the inner accretion disk as well as the origin and maintenance of the large-scale magnetic fields believed to power relativistic jets, and then will be made publicly available to the research community. The network will contribute to scientific workforce development by supporting the work of undergraduate students, graduate students, and postdocs; and a program of visualizations, released on the internet, will help communicate the excitement of black hole astrophysics to the scientific community and to the broader public.

POR.DRECONTENT:
When black holes accrete matter from their surroundings, they produce
powerful relativistic outflows of matter and become some of the
most luminous objects in the known Universe.  Thus, the theory of
how matter accretes in to black holes is central to many areas of
modern astrophysics.  This project was a collaboration between
researchers at Princeton University, the University of Illinois,
and the University of California Berkeley to study black hole
accretion in two very important regimes: (1) systems with
very high accretion rates where radiation forces are important, and
(2) systems with very low accretion rates where collisionless plasma
effects are important.

Significant advances were made in both regimes.  For luminous
accretion flows, we developed powerful new numerical methods for
studying radiation-dominated magnetized plasmas.  We used the nations
largest supercomputers, with access provided by the DOE INCITE
program, to run the largest numerical calculations to date that
follow radiation-dominated black hole accretion flows.  We discovered
new phenomena, for example spiral density waves dominate angular
momentumm transport in highly radiation pressure dominated disks.
For the first time, we were able to compute what fraction of the energy
released by accretion is radiated away, what fraction goes in to
driving outflows which impact their surroundings, and what fraction
is accreted into the black hole.  These results are important for
understanding systems such as active galactic nuclei.  Attached is
an image from one of our simulations.

For low-luminosity accretion flows, we were able to use advanced
numerical methods to compute the dynamics of collisionless plasmas
and study angular momentum transport and magnetically-driven turbulence
in this regime.  We showed that even in weakly collisional plasmas,
the dynamics is well-modeled by simpler mathematical models such as magneto-hydrodynamics.  Our results help explain observations of the black
hole at the center of our own Milky Way galaxy.  Attached is an
image of our calculations in this regime.

Our work has advanced our understanding of these important astrophysical
systems.  We developed and have made publically available new
numerical codes that can be used to study a variety of problems in
plasma physics, these codes have already been downloaded hundreds
of times by research groups around the world.  Nearly half a dozen
postdoctoral research associates participated in this collaboration,
many of whom have gone on to research positions at universities and
the national labs.  We ran a very popular summer school for
undergraduates on numerical methods for plasma physics, with over
100 students from around the country participating.  This project
was a major part of the PhD thesis of two graduate students at
Princeton, and also supported two undergraduate summer research
projects at Princeton (both students involved have enrolled in PhD
programs in physics).  Finally, we published numerous refereed
papers, gave dozens of research talks and seminars, and to desseminate
our results more widely to the public, we created animations,
visualizations, and wrote several popular-level reviews on our
results.
